packs.yarn_name: Crystal Palace Yarns Cotton Chenille Solid

104321.name: Breast Prosthesis
104321.notes_html: Jenny wanted to do something useful and this came about because of Beryl Tsang’s “Titbits” which is the original knitted version. Jenny cant knit so wanted to offer her crochet skills. This free pattern is available from jenny direct… her sizing is a bit out though make a smaller size than needed. Eventually it will be a PDF. Fine super soft threads are needed as the skin is usually tender. The one photographed is also the basic model. Beryl’s were made in fun threads with pierced nipples etc. Plastic bear pellets were used to add weight to the “breast” to help it stay in a bra and not pop out

users.fave_colors: yellow , orange and LIME, yet Hot pink keeps sneaking on in
users.about_me:
Crochet designer and teacher. I have authored 20 Crochet Pattern books and have taught crochet all over the world including Knit and Crochet Now TV show.

 I developed and trademarked the top-down phenomenon which is Get Squared and Kids Squared which allows any weight yarn to be used to create great seamless wearables with only 2 measurements for perfect fit first time every time.

 I am a proud Professional Member of the Crochet Guild of Americal and one of the founders of Crochet Guild Australia.

 I love designing wearables and specialize in interesting Size Inclusive designs that I LOVE to wear.

Crochet designer and teacher. I have authored 20 Crochet Pattern books and have taught crochet all over the world including Knit and Crochet Now TV show.

I developed and trademarked the top-down phenomenon which is Get Squared and Kids Squared which allows any weight yarn to be used to create great seamless wearables with only 2 measurements for perfect fit first time every time.

I am a proud Professional Member of the Crochet Guild of Americal and one of the founders of Crochet Guild Australia.

I love designing wearables and specialize in interesting Size Inclusive designs that I LOVE to wear.

117181.name: Deflowered
117181.gauge_description: 20 stitches and 32 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
117181.notes_html:
This menstrual cup cozy pattern is part of the Fertility Party Pack Pattern Set- all patterns are included in the same pdf.

This pattern set is made up of 5 patterns that deal with stages of a woman’s fertility. Each pattern includes the information of what is needed to complete that individual project.

“ Both Goddess and God are aware of each other as loving companions and playmates, who know that they are made for each other and that one day in the not too distant future they will lie together to experience the ecstasy of love.” p. 77 in Seasons of the Witch by Gail Duff (2002)

users.fave_colors: I love all color (as long as it doesn't look like anything yucky)!
users.about_me:
I can't remember a time when I wasn't influenced by fiber arts.  My grandmother was a knitter, my mother a weaver, and I'm a firm believer that the reason Romney is one of my favorite breeds is that my mother raised some when I was a baby. Now it's not just in my blood, it's what I do. I have an **[Etsy Shop][3]** full of my creations and I work part time from home for **[Colorsong Yarn][4]**. My husband is an incredibly tolerant man. He combats my fiber addiction and need to have lots of pets by buying industrial sized lint rollers. 

We met and married in Oregon in 2007 and have since lived in UT, CA, AZ, CO, OR, MT and as of Sept 2016 we live outside of Portland, OR in West Linn on what we home to turn into a small urban farm. We have a preschooler daughter, a baby daughter, 1 dog, 1 cat, and 6 chickens. 

When I'm not knitting or spinning I can be found in the kitchen, out in the garden, at the sewing machine, or out in the wilderness. 

**You can find me all over the internet:**

Check out my Etsy Store for my hand  spun yarn and fun and funky spinning batts and other fibers-   [BohoKnitterChic Spins][6]. 

Join my [Mailing List][7]

I have a  group on Ravelry: [BohoKnitterChic  Spins][8] 

Become a fan of mine at the   [BohoKnitterChic Spins Facebook Fan Page][9] for news and pics of what's   happening with my etsy shop and   knitting patterns. 
 

![alt text][10]


  [3]: http://bohoknitterchic.etsy.com/
  [4]: http://www.colorsongyarn.com
  [6]: http://www.etsy.com/shop.php?user_id=5776752 
  [7]: http://eepurl.com/bCA_z
  [8]: http://www.ravelry.com/groups/bohoknitterchic-spins
  [9]: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Bohemian-Knitter-Chic/168650308926
  [10]: http://assets3.ravelry.com/assets/31234625/Ravelry_Group_Banner_banner.jpg

118789.name: "Kitty" Eye Patch
118789.notes_html: “Kitty” is a an eye patch originially designed for my daughter who has a lazy eye. It is one size, but you could easily size up by adding more length to the I-cord. When not in use as an eye patch it can also be worn as a headband.
118789.notes: "Kitty" is a an eye patch originially designed for my daughter who has a lazy eye.  It is one size, but you could easily size up by adding more length to the I-cord.  When not in use as an eye patch it can also be worn as a headband.

pattern_author.name: Christine H. Wilkins
pattern_author.notes: I have been designing clothing since I was sixteen.  I started designing knitted garments just a couple of years ago when the need for something particular that I could not find anywhere else arose.  My eye and my needles always tend toward functional and feminine as the first inspirations for many new ideas.

143790.name: Knitted Rice Bags
143790.sizes_available: Pattern can be made in various sizes
143790.notes_html:
This is a general pattern for knitted rice bags. I used almost a complete skein of Lily Sugar’n Cream Twists, or approximately 100 yards. If you make them in other sizes, plan for 1.5 skeins for added yardage.

These rice bags are great for aches and pain. All you need to do is heat them up in the microwave for 2 minutes and place it where you hurt. It isn’t as effective as a prescription, but it can be a non-drug alternative in between your pain medications.

Cotton yarn should be used for this project. Cotton retains heat well and will not catch fire in the microwave.

Gauge is approximate and does not need to be exact.
Yardage is based on the general pattern. If modifying the pattern for a larger size, more yardage is required.

The pattern requires you to be able to sew a rectangle, but it does not need to be perfect and pretty because it will be hiding inside the knitted rice bag.
143790.notes:
This is a general pattern for knitted rice bags. I used almost a complete skein of Lily Sugar'n Cream Twists, or approximately 100 yards. If you make them in other sizes, plan for 1.5 skeins for added yardage.

These rice bags are great for aches and pain. All you need to do is heat them up in the microwave for 2 minutes and place it where you hurt. It isn’t as effective as a prescription, but it can be a non-drug alternative in between your pain medications.

Cotton yarn should be used for this project. Cotton retains heat well and will not catch fire in the microwave. 

Gauge is approximate and does not need to be exact. 
Yardage is based on the general pattern. If modifying the pattern for a larger size, more yardage is required.

The pattern requires you to be able to sew a rectangle, but it does not need to be perfect and pretty because it will be hiding inside the knitted rice bag.

users.fave_colors: rich tones of just about any color - cranberry and christmas reds, gorgeous pink shades, emerald green, rich ocean blues, rustic orange and gold, soft tones of sage green or yellows, purples, charcoal greys, chocolate browns, teal ...
users.fave_curse: I find myself saying the word a**hole when I am driving in LA traffic more each day.
users.about_me:
I taught myself knitting and crocheting, and now I have quite a library of books, dvd's and patterns. 

I started with crochet, but am more of a knitter who wishes she could do more amigurumi! I have a handful of patterns I designed, and have chronicles of some of my life when I lived with chronic illness and was on disability on an old Wordpress blog: [https://www.kkhymn.wordpress.com][1]

My creative mojo has saved me through the ups and downs of that journey in my life. And I now have a coaching and consultant business that connects all the dots and stitches together - [Resilient Leader Solutions][2].

I practice random acts of kindness as a part of my every day life, and I give my hand made items to those in need of a hug to fight their own battles.


  [1]: https://www.kkhymn.wordpress.com/
  [2]: https://www.resilientleadersolutions.com

My creative mojo has saved me through the ups and downs of that journey in my life. And I now have a coaching and consultant business that connects all the dots and stitches together - Resilient Leader Solutions.

I practice random acts of kindness as a part of my every day life, and I give my hand made items to those in need of a hug to fight their own battles.

162189.name: Residual Limb Covers for Amputees
162189.yarn_weight_description: Any gauge - designed for any gauge
162189.notes_html:
“Bear in mind that these patterns are intended for adults; socks for below-knee amputees would necessarily be longer (10-12”) than those for above-knee amputations. Adaptations for children’s or women’s sizes or for arm/wrist amputations can be made by using finer yarns and/or smaller needles, but the basic pattern remains constant. One variation we have tried was to make the sock ribbing about 8” long, then change to plain stockinette for an inch or so before the decreases; this made a snug but very flexible fit.” Barbara

Variations for DK, sport, and worsted weight yarns.

Could be done for those in Haiti, too, although not of wool, I would think.
162189.notes:
"Bear in mind that these patterns are intended for adults; socks for below-knee amputees would necessarily be longer (10-12") than those for above-knee amputations. Adaptations for children's or women's sizes or for arm/wrist amputations can be made by using finer yarns and/or smaller needles, but the basic pattern remains constant. One variation we have tried was to make the sock ribbing about 8" long, then change to plain stockinette for an inch or so before the decreases; this made a snug but very flexible fit."  *Barbara*

Variations for DK, sport, and worsted weight yarns. 

Could be done for those in Haiti, too, although not of wool, I would think.

users.fave_curse: Well, they've just about all got their uses, haven't they?
users.about_me:
Hi, my name is Jess, and I am an addict. I'm addicted to crocheting and knitting. Give me a bent stick or pointy ones and some yarn, and I will be happy for hours. I've even crocheted with a bent paperclip in a fix!

I love color. And I like yarn more than most of the people I know.

I just love color and texture and the feel of yarn in my hands.

210368.name: Butterfly Hot or Cold Pack
210368.gauge_description: 34 stitches and 41 rows = 4 inches in single crochet (US)
210368.notes_html:
Skill Level: Intermediate

Materials:
• Aunt Lydia’s Classic Crochet size 10 crochet cotton (350 yds per ball): 1 ball each #449 forest green, #661 frosty green, #423 maize, #401 orchid pink, #480 delft, #458 purple and #131 fudge brown
• Size 7/1.65mm steel crochet hook or size needed to obtain gauge

Loop-n-Lace Afghans

Super Easy Baby Blankets
30 Gifts in 30 Days
Dream Catchers
Baby Shower Cakes
When Granny Meets Filet
Charted Picture Afghans
Knit 1, Purl 2 in Crochet
Learn to do Surface Stitches
T-Shirt Dresses & Accessories
Blocks and Borders for Baby Blankets
Adorable Baby Clothes
Single Crochet from A to Z
Dying to Crochet (a crochet murder mystery book)
Beaded Neck Candy
Crochet on the Edge
Curling Ribbon Home Accents
Curling Ribbon Holiday Accents

My favorite stitches are post stitches, surface chain stitches, slip stitches, etc.  I love texture.

221705.name: Round Ice Bag
221705.notes_html:
The ice bag’s shape is modeled on the Bonjour Baby Beret. There are some structural changes, and it’s smaller, but the shape is very much the same.

I thought it would be nice to have an ice bag around the house - in case anyone gets bumps and bruises from New Year’s resolution workouts.

The pattern has a typo. Where it says “knit to to stitches before marker,” it should saw “knit to two stitches before marker.”

The website that previously hosted this has dropped all of my old patterns. They are currently unavailable, but I may reissue them at another time.
221705.notes:
The ice bag's shape is modeled on the [Bonjour Baby Beret][1]. There are some structural changes, and it's smaller, but the shape is very much the same.

  [1]: http://www.ravelry.com/patterns/library/bonjour-baby-beret

The pattern has a typo. Where it says "knit to to stitches before marker," it should saw "knit to two stitches before marker."


**The website that previously hosted this has dropped all of my old patterns. They are currently unavailable, but I may reissue them at another time.**

pattern_author.name: Lara Neel
pattern_author.notes:
Co-Author of Crafting the Resistance, due out in August, 2017, from Skyhorse Publishing.

Author of Sock Architecture, a book to inspire the most awesome socks you ever knit, published by Cooperative Press in September, 2014.

**Warning: The website that hosted the Math4Knitters, Crafty Living blog changed systems in mid-December, 2014. Those links are no longer active.**

For more information about me, take a look at [my personal website][1] and [Math4Knitters blog][2]. I also have written a blog about [eating, cooking and living gluten-free][3], but it's pretty dormant right now.

I am a knitting, designing, math diva podcaster and author.


  [1]: http://www.laraneel.com
  [2]: http://www.math4knitters.blogspot.com/
  [3]: http://feedingdee.blogspot.com/

users.about_me:
I am a knitting, designing, math diva podcaster at math4knitters.blogspot.com. 

I'm a Craftsy instructor! [Go check out my sock class][1]!

I'm the author of Sock Architecture, a book to inspire the most awesome socks you ever knit (or just make one of the 17 patterns in the book).

My second book, Crafting the Resistance, is due out in August of 2017. [It's available for preorder now][2].

My Etsy site, where you can buy signed copies of my book, is here: https://www.etsy.com/shop/laraneel

I blog about design inspiration, knitting, spinning, weaving, and anything else I like [here][3].

I published over 150 free patterns in three years for the Math4Knitters: Crafty Living blog. (Those patterns are unavailable, as of December 2014, because they redesigned their website.) Now, I'm offering select, test-knit (and/or tech edited) patterns for sale.

My personal website is [here][4].
 
I also (used to) write a blog about [eating, living and cooking gluten-free][5]. I still use those recipes!


  [1]: http://www.craftsy.com/ext/LaraNeel_5058_F
  [2]: https://www.amazon.com/Crafting-Resistance-Projects-Craftivists-Protestors/dp/1510731385/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1494617546&sr=8-1&keywords=crafting+the+resistance
  [3]: http://www.math4knitters.blogspot.com/
  [4]: http://laraneel.com/
  [5]: http://feedingdee.blogspot.com/

My second book, Crafting the Resistance, is due out in August of 2017. It’s available for preorder now.

My Etsy site, where you can buy signed copies of my book, is here: https://www.etsy.com/shop/laraneel

I blog about design inspiration, knitting, spinning, weaving, and anything else I like here.

I published over 150 free patterns in three years for the Math4Knitters: Crafty Living blog. (Those patterns are unavailable, as of December 2014, because they redesigned their website.) Now, I’m offering select, test-knit (and/or tech edited) patterns for sale.

My personal website is here.

I also (used to) write a blog about eating, living and cooking gluten-free. I still use those recipes!

225858.name: Crutches Cozy
225858.notes_html:
Hope you or your loved one heals quickly :)

Feel Better!
225858.notes:
Hope you or your loved one heals quickly :)

**Feel Better!**

226822.name: Midwifery Baby Scale Sling
226822.gauge_description: 15 stitches and 22 rows = 4 inches in stockinette stitch
226822.notes_html:
This is a perfect gift or project for a homebirth midwife or new mother!

The sling is knit directly onto 2 metal ring sling rings. To weigh baby: lay flat, place baby in center, perpendicular to the long edge, bring up the rings, hang from the hook of a hanging scale.

(Safety note: not for use as a baby carrier or baby sleeping space! Use only for determining weight with a hanging scale, held over a soft surface.)
226822.notes:
This is a perfect gift or project for a homebirth midwife or new mother!

The sling is knit directly onto 2 metal ring sling rings. To weigh baby: lay flat, place baby in center, perpendicular to the long edge, bring up the rings, hang from the hook of a hanging scale.

(Safety note: not for use as a baby carrier or baby sleeping space! Use only for determining weight with a hanging scale, held over a soft surface.)

228538.name: heat pack
228538.gauge_description: 8 stitches  = 2 inches in double crochet, US
228538.notes_html:
i was needing a pattern for one of these, and couldn’t find anyting to suit my needs. experimentation, anyone?

anyway, you should wind up with a nice ribbing every inch or so, and cute bows on the sides. also, i reccomend not using red.

Stomach warmer
This is to help get rid of cramps, something I have a lot of trouble with. It consists of a crocheted cover and a cloth bag made out of the material of your choice. Try to avoid polyester, as I’m not sure how well it would do in the microwave. To use, pop the bag in the microwave to warm it up to a comforting temprature, then slide it back inside the cover so you don’t burn your poor belly!

anyway, you should wind up with a nice ribbing every inch or so, and cute bows on the sides. also, i reccomend not using red. 


Stomach warmer
This is to help get rid of cramps, something I have a lot of trouble with. It consists of a crocheted cover and a cloth bag made out of the material of your choice. Try to avoid polyester, as I’m not sure how well it would do in the microwave. To use, pop the bag in the microwave to warm it up to a comforting temprature, then slide it back inside the cover so you don’t burn your poor belly!

pattern_author.name: Mariel Redwood
pattern_author.notes: i'm a homeschooled teen living in michigan who loves to crochet, but can rarely find patterns to make exactly what i want. so, i started designing my own and ended up posting them on my blog and Ravelry!

packs.personal_name: Lilly's Sugar and Cream Cotton Yarn

242367.name: Menstrual Pads
242367.notes_html:
Sizes: Mini Pad (or pantyliner), Small and Large Menstrual Pad.
Lengths: 18, 25 and 28 cm (7”, 10” and 11”).

The pad is made of three layers. A soft and absorbent knitted layer of bamboo yarn, an absorbent core and to prevent leakage a layer of polar fleece. The layers are sewn together on a sewing machine.

The pattern instruction is build up as a chart.

Dansk

Størrelser: Trusseindlæg, lille og stort bind.
Længde: 18, 25 og 28 cm.

Bindet består af tre lag. En blød og sugende overflade strikket i bambusgarn; en sugende kerne; samt en lækagebarriere af fleece. Lagene er syet sammen på symaskine.

Opskriften på den strikkede del er bygget op omkring et mønsterdiagram.

Du kan læse mere om baggrunden for projektet her: www.paapinden.dk/blog/indlaeg.php?aar=2011&post=017

pattern_author.name: Irene Birk
pattern_author.notes:
.

My pattern site (en/da): [www.knittingdane.com][1]
My Danish knitting site: [www.paapinden.dk][2]

A couple of my patterns are written as universal patterns (Ragnas Rib, Devils Cap and Nursing Pads). With these patterns you can knit any size at any gauge according to your own measurements. Just choose your yarn and needle, measure your baby and calculate your stitches. Hereby get a perfect fit.

The rest of my patterns are written as regular knitting patterns.


  [1]: http://www.knittingdane.com
  [2]: http://www.paapinden.dk
pattern_author.notes_html:
.

My pattern site (en/da): www.knittingdane.com
My Danish knitting site: www.paapinden.dk

A couple of my patterns are written as universal patterns (Ragnas Rib, Devils Cap and Nursing Pads). With these patterns you can knit any size at any gauge according to your own measurements. Just choose your yarn and needle, measure your baby and calculate your stitches. Hereby get a perfect fit.

The rest of my patterns are written as regular knitting patterns.
